Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: reading, writing, speaking, and understanding Chinese -- also learned about Chinese culture as a byproduct of studying the language
I better learned how to write formally in Chinese as well as how to increase sentence structure diversity and write so that my Chinese would flow better.
I learned Mandarin grammar, speaking, and writing.
Speaking, reading, and writing Chinese at an advanced level
This class helped me develop my speaking and writing skills as a heritage learner.
Developed a greater Chinese vocabulary and also a greater understanding of Chinese culture.

Chinese 142 is a substantial jump in difficulty from Chinese 132, but the course remains excellent. Techniques developed include memorization and a lot of it, but the amount of class engagement makes memorizing all the characters worth it.

I learned what study habits are most effective for myself. I learned a wealth of knowledge in the Chinese language and now can confidently speak with my parents in my native language. I gained insight in how to interpret Chinese characters for not only what they represent, but also why they represent those things.
Memorized hundreds of characters; reading and writing and grammar skills developed; vocab greatly expanded

Continuing from 132, I further learned how to speak, listen, read, and write about social issues, politics, and aspects of Chinese culture. 142 was definitely more rigorous, than 132, and I had to learn to more quickly grasp the greater volume of increasingly difficult grammar structure and vocabulary. From the in class presentations, I got more comfortable with my presentation skills, both in general and in Chinese.

Strengths: the professors really get to know you and help you improve your language skills through a personal level. They know each and every one of their students flaws and fixes them accordingly which in my opinion, really helped improve my Chinese skills

strengths: encourages you to partake in the Chinese language daily
weaknesses: may have stressed memorizing characters a bit too much, rather than having plentiful relaxed discussions
I wish there were more discussion based classes.

This course really helps you learn Chinese through daily quizzes, but I often feel like it does come down to brute force memorization. Of course, this is due to the nature of the language and I'm not sure how much they could do to change that, but be warned, there is a lot of character memorization. Despite this, the teachers are very interactive and try their best to make the class interesting for the students, which is greatly appreciated.
The course is extremely structured and effective in teaching.
Great course for retaining and learning Chinese characters, as well as student engagement.

The class is excellent, just like every other Chinese class at Yale. One will probably come close to freaking out after realizing that theres still a seemingly endless amount of Chinese homework to be done every day, but its worth it.

I think a strength of this class is the consistency in what you expect from the daily class, so that you know precisely how much time is required for work.

There are not many weaknesses that I can think of; this is an extremely effective and useful class for teaching a language.
I think we spend too little time on grammar. I wish we could also spend in-class time constructing essays/sentences as a class (more holistic approach).

Great teachers who really know what they're doing; There's daily homework, but it definitely helps you learn to use the vocab and grammar structures rather than just being able to recognize them. Answer keys with suggested responses for the homework practice problems would be great for studying for exams. I think the course could also be improved by letting us have more opportunities to practice speaking outside of class and not just for the presentation days -  perhaps doing recordings like the higher level Chinese classes would help.
Yes definitely. The class is rigorous but by the time you finish, you will see a drastic improvement in your language skills
yes, because it definitely improved my Chinese skills manifold
Liu Laoshi is an amazing professor. Definitely take esp. for your language requirement.
I would recommend this course if you are a native Chinese speaker who never really learned to read and write.
The course was fantastic and although it was difficult to manage the workload at times, it was extremely rewarding
Yes! Would highly recommend. Liu laoshi and Chan laoshi are super sweet and do everything to help you learn and understand better.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone looking to complete their language requirement. This class is a lot of work, so I would not recommend taking it CR/D.
Yes! Its a great class for Heritage speakers of Chinese and a definite must-take for those who took L3 Heritage Chinese.
I would 100% recommend because of Liu Laoshi and Chan Laoshi! They are amazing kind caring professors who really want you to improve your Chinese but also care about you as a student.

Yes, 100%! Liu Laoshi is an amazing teacher and human being, and I love coming to class because it's essentially a very chill discussion. If you're looking to take a Chinese class for language requirement or just to learn Chinese, I'd highly recommend this class. The workload is significantly greater than CHNS 132, but I also learned a lot more from this class and found that I could adapt to the greater amount of vocab and grammar that we had to learn each week.
